text: the keynote speaker this morning and you're all looking forward to a full day of learning more about AWS my name is Zach Musgrave and I'm a
software development engineer on the AWS sdks and tools team my team owns the AWS
SDK for Java which is a set of client libraries for every AWS service that
Amazon web services offers it also includes a bunch of utilities and useful libraries that help you get more out of
the services and make you more productive my team also produces the AWS toolkit for Eclipse which is the subject
of this talk the toolkit is a set of eclipse plugins which bring the eclipse sorry
which bring the AWS Cloud right into your Eclipse workbench and let you view
and manage and interact with your AWS resources right from inside your [Music]
IDE you're here today because you think that the Eclipse IDE is the best way to
develop Java software Eclipse integrates your text editor your compiler and your runtime
test environment all into one place so that you don't have to switch context as often as you're developing your
application but Eclipse isn't just about writing code more than that it also
brings other resources things like your database servers your file system any
sort of uh web servers that you may be running it brings those into your into your Eclipse
workbench uh it makes them just as accessible as the code that you're writing
writing on the sdks and tools team we believe that your AWS resources things
like your S3 buckets and your Dynamo DB tables these things should be just as
accessible from your E clips workbench as your local file system a local database server or a local Tomcat
server these they should be just as well integrated into your Eclipse workbench and should be first class
citizens so I'm here today to demonstrate some of the features of the toolkit and to show how you can use them
to give you greater Clarity into your development process to save you time and frustration and to drive the quality of
the software that you build you're going to learn how easy it is to view and to manage your AWS
resources right from inside your Eclipse workbench you're going to see how to use
Eclipse to deploy a web application directly from the eclip work Eclipse workbench into AWS elastic beanock
and you're going to learn how to connect eclipse's remote debugger to that running beanock application along the way you're going
to learn some best practices for how to architect your application to achieve reliability scalability and
performance the product that we're going to be building today should be familiar to almost everyone in this
room it's called a meme generator which is also known as an image macro generator
and this is a web application which allows your customers to Overlay a couple captions of their choice onto
some well-known image and then share it with their friends to get a to get a laugh I have this running in a web
browser so let's switch over there and take a tour of what it
offers so the first page of the application just lets you choose one of the blank images to write text onto so
we'll choose Arnold here and we'll say oops
say need more coffee tell I've done this before and
then when you click create meme the gears are going to turn in the background and then your text gets
overlaid onto that image and you can share it with your friends of course there's also a button which you can
click to see all the memes that people have created there's the one we just created there I'll point out one of my
one of my favorites one of my colleagues came up with this when we were when we were doing our run through of this talk
so you can see the URL in the browser bar there so if you anytime you feel
like you're nodding off and you can't pay attention to the talk just go ahead and browse the application and see what
memes people have created and contribute some of your own and we'll be coming back here for
the rest of the talk on a regular basis to see what people have come up
with so the next step is to see how we created this project in Eclipse but before we do that we need
need to understand a little bit about the system how it's architected and how it all fits together with AWS
Services under the hood this application uses a very common AWS architectural
design pattern on the left side of this architectural diagram you can see the web UI environment which is an elastic
beant stock environment and that's the that's the component which handles all
the interaction with the customer and serves all the JSP pages and so on then on the other side of the diagram there's
a fleet of ec2 workers nodes and these are just interchangeable nodes that handle all of the image processing on
the back end so that the web UI environment doesn't need to be burdened with that task then down the middle of the diagram
kind of the backbone of the architecture we use three of the most common and most useful and Powerful AWS infrastructure
Services first we're using Amazon S3 to store all of the images for the
application and this includes not only the blank meme images for people to write uh text onto but also all the
finished captioned memes that people have already created next we use Amazon Dynamo DB to
store the metadata for all of these meme creation jobs and the finished memes this includes things like the the S3 key
of the image that we use to write the text onto as well as the captions that the customer applied and some various
various bits of bookkeeping information finally we use Amazon simple Q service to equally distribute the load
of creating new memes onto that backend Fleet of worker nodes on the left side of the diagram
outside the cloud bubble we see a a couple of customer web browsers now I will point out that
arguably this architecture is a little bit of overkill for the workload that we're going to be throwing at it uh
specifically you could probably get rid of the backend Fleet of worker nodes as well as the queue that's serving their
their work to them and the application wouldn't really suffer this architecture is really better suited for something
that's very processor intensive something like video processing or or some other very heavy workload in any
case something that should never be performed in the context of a of a web UI environment we could easily just
process the memes on the web UI environments and it would probably be fine but this this architecture does
suit our purposes today which is first to show off some of the features of the AWS toolkit and second to give you ideas for
Best Practices so that when you do go out into the world and build those really heavy duty crunching number crunching applications you'll know how
to proceed and and be confident that your application's not going to fall
over next we need to know a little bit about how data flows through this system to understand how we can interact with
it through a clipse the first thing that happens when a customer uh visits the web page is that a JSP page pulls S3 to
ask for all of the blank meme images in a particular bucket such as this adorable kitty cat the customer sees all
these images as we saw and then selects one writes some text and initiates a post to another JSP page this JSP then
is going to do a couple things with AWS services in order to kick off that Meme creation
workflow the first thing that it does is insert a new item into Amazon Dynamo
DB this item contains everything that the system needs to know to create that New Meme image with the captions that
the customer specified next that JSP page is going to
insert a new message into our Amazon simple Q service Q now the body of this
message is simply the ID number or or actually the ID string of the item that we just inserted into Dynamo
DB from this point forward the JSP page is not going to do anything except wait
and pull Dynamo DB periodically checking on the status of that Meme creation job that it inserted and finally when it
sees that it that that job status has transitioned to done it will display the finished meme back to the
customer now on the backend side of things the process happens in the reverse
order first the fleet of worker nodes is going to pull sqs asking for some work to do and again
the the message that it gets back from sqs is simply the ID of an item in Dynamo DB that it should look up to use
to perform its uh its meme creation job it's going to load that item from
Dynamo DB using that ID and at this point the backend fleet has knows everything that it needs to know in
order to create that Meme for the customer it'll download the appropriate
object from S3 then process the job writing the
appropriate text onto the image and then upload that image back into S3 finally it will update the dynamodb
item which lets the JSP page waiting know that this meme creation job has now finished and you can show the final
product to the customer and that's the last thing that happens the customer sees the the finished meem that they requested on
their screen now I wrote this application
entirely with an eclipse using the AWS toolkit for eclipse and that includes not only
writing all the code that the application uses but also creating and managing and editing all the AWS
resources that the application needs to run I'm not going to take you through line
by line how to write this very simple application but I am going to show you exactly how you can use the AWS toolkit
for Clips to manage the AWS resources that are used by the application the toolkit features two
main starting points which you can see on the screen right now on the left is a screenshot of the AWS new Java project
wizard this is a new project wizard much like the standard Java project wizard you would use to create a new Java
project that performs a couple pieces of automation to help get you up and running with a new AWS connected Java
project very quickly on the right side of the screen you can see the AWS Explorer view this
is an eclipse view which is kind of analogous to the file explorer view except instead of the file hierarchy you
see the hierarchy of uh AWS services and you can view and interact with the with
their contents so let's go ahead and drop down into eclipse
and we'll demo how to create a new AWS Java project so to create a new AWS Java
project we just right click in the package Explorer just as we would if we were creating a standard Java project
and you can see the new AWS Java project menu option there so I just select
that and here this is a pretty standard uh wizard just as if you were creating a
non AWS connection Java project so we'll type a project name
reinvent demo and then the the Wizard asks for a couple other pieces of
information that you should Supply the first is this AWS credentials
section the toolkit will manage as many different AWS accounts as you want and
store all the credentials your access key and your secret key for those accounts so that you can use them when
you're writing your applications and we'll see how that works in a minute if this is your first time using the plugin you can always click on this
configure AWS accounts link and this opens up the preference page where you can configure as many AWS accounts as
you want storing the access key and secret key you can see I have two accounts set up and they have different information
associated with them I can of course add a new account I'm not going to do that right
now so here I'm prompted to select one of those two accounts I'm going to stick with the eclipse account that was
already highlighted the second bit of information which you can see here are these little portions of sample code and
I can choose as many of these as I want these are very simple sample applications that get you up and running
quickly with the service of your choice they show you how to do things like instantiate a service client and
make a couple different service calls that you're likely to need when you're uh when you're working with a particular
service and these are a great way to get up and running quickly when you're new to a service and you're don't really want to browse through the documentation
and just want to start writing code immediately so we're going ahead and click the Amazon S3 sample and this is a
very simple uh S3 application which creates a bucket uploads an object to it
downloads that object again and then cleans up after Itself by deleting the bucket so if we click next we can see

there's really no need to do that for right now so we'll just click finish and here's our new

for Java class path container and if I expand that you can see that it contains not only the SDK
for Java jar itself but also all of the third party libraries that the SDK
requires to run properly all that's set up for us on our behalf we don't have to deal with
it the next piece of automation is this AWS credentials. properties file this is
just a Java properties file that contains your access key and your secret key and Eclipse puts it in a place where

this S3 sample. Java here we can see that it's setting up an Amazon S3 client for us using that
AWS credentials. properties file oops not a very good Circle that we found on our class path so because the toolkit

it and clean up after ourselves and the reason this can work right out of the box is because Eclipse
knows about your AWS credentials and stores them on your behalf so that's the new Java project
Wizard and the second launching off point is this AWS Explorer view I'm

if I want to open this View for the first time I can just write I can just click on this drop down menu with the

up so what we're looking at here is a hierarchical tree view of all the Amazon

Fleet of image worker or image processing nodes is pulling messages off the queue as fast as it can and then
